title: Frik du Preez
text:
Frederik Christoffel Hendrik "Frik" du Preez (born 28 November 1935) is a former South African <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player who represented <a href="Blue%20Bulls">Northern Transvaal</a> and the <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Springboks</a>. He was born on a farm near <a href="Rustenburg">Rustenburg</a> and went to school at <a href="Parys%20High%20School">Parys High School</a> in <a href="Parys">Parys</a> (<a href="Free%20State%20Province">Orange Free State</a>). Du Preez mostly played in the <a href="Flanker%20%28rugby%20union%29">flank</a> or <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Loose%20forward%20/%20Lock%20forward">lock</a> positions.
Du Preez made his <a href="Rugby%20union%23Major%20international%20competitions">test</a> debut for the Springboks on 7 January 1961 in the flank position against <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a> at <a href="Twickenham%20Stadium">Twickenham</a>. He played his last test on 7 August 1971 at the age of 35 as a lock against <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Australia</a> at the <a href="Sydney%20Cricket%20Ground">Sydney Cricket Ground</a>.
Du Preez was an excellent all-round footballer, and like Australian lock <a href="John%20Eales">John Eales</a>, he was that rare phenomenon: a <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Loose%20forward%20/%20Lock%20forward">lock</a> that could kick and even drop kick. Although he was not particularly tall, he was a tower of strength in the line-out. In addition he had a fantastic turn of speed and fine running skills with ball in hand, as he showed in the try he scored against the <a href="British%20and%20Irish%20Lions">British Lions</a> in 1968.
As an expression of the esteem that he is held in by South African rugby fans, Du Preez was named the country's rugby player of the 20th century.
